body: I saw this code to be able to understand what was happening on my problem, but I am not sure if it's a PHP issue. In theory this hour does not exist. I created this issue here to see what the community would say about this, or at least help me to figure out a good solution. Thanks anyway
@macropay-solutions  because I'm validating if the string has a valid date format. This situation I'm passing a valid date format...

More interesting is the + 6 months change for DST when 3 AM becomes 2 AM resulting in multiple 2 equal  date time strings that point to 2 different moments in time.

2025-09-30 02:10:10 ..... 2025-09-30 02:59:59|2025-09-30 02:00:00...2025-09-30 02:10:10

This is why we always store date times in UTC and if needed we format them to local only when they need to be displayed.

>@macropay-solutions because I'm validating if the string has a valid date format. This situation I'm passing a valid date format...

As per docs

>[date_format:format,...](https://laravel.com/docs/12.x/validation#rule-date-format)
The field under validation must match one of the given formats. You should use either date or date_format when validating a field, not both. This validation rule supports all formats supported by PHP's [DateTime](https://www.php.net/manual/en/class.datetime.php) class.

>For convenience, date-based rules may be constructed using the fluent date rule builder:

>use Illuminate\Validation\Rule;
 
>'start_date' => [
    'required',
    Rule::date()->format('Y-m-d'),
],

date_format implies valid date
I'm using timestamp as date column on mysql database, and I am setting the connection to use the user's timezone. Which in this case it would save in UTC, no?

From the internet for mysql  https://medium.com/@kenny_7143/time-zone-in-mysql-e7b73c70fd4e
>The TIMESTAMP data type stores values in UTC internally and automatically converts them to the current session's time zone upon retrieval.
@crynobone nice fix, congrats. It is ok to pass as valid a non existing date time in this case?
Application should always use UTC and only output to the user based on configured timezone. This is the main reason why `app.timezone` has been removed

@crynobone app.timezone is still in app.php config stub in version 12. https://github.com/laravel/framework/blob/aa671fd476233b5df894445351a562f14b95a4d3/config-stubs/app.php#L68

And also in config app.php

https://github.com/laravel/framework/blob/aa671fd476233b5df894445351a562f14b95a4d3/config/app.php#L75

Or you mean the env variable was removed?
